text.sentence: Consumer | U.S. Food and Drug Retailing one October two thousand fifteen
COST generally plays its cards very close, and that was visible in the discussion on two important topics on the fourQfifteen earnings call.

First, management would not comment on the benefit of changing vendors for its dual branded credit card to Citi/Visa from Amex, even though they have said the new deal is more attractive financially to COST.
All they added yesterday was that the company generally shares these kinds of benefits with customers by lowering prices or boosting the product value.
Second, the company was asked about a membership fee increase, which has not happened in four years and is generally done every five years.
Management's was slightly clearer ­ but negative ­ on this topic, saying that there hadn't been much discussion internally on the topic.

COST was also unwilling to say anything about future stock repurchases, though the view was reiterated that buybacks are on the list of acceptable uses of cash, and COST will usually buy back a bit more stock when the price drops.
New warehouse growth was disappointing in FYfifteen, with a net twenty three of openings vs. original guidance of thirty as some stores slipped into FYsixteen; such slippage is common within retail.
International can be particularly challenging ­ most notably in Europe ­ because of zoning and other regulatory limitations.
The guidance for FYsixteen is for a net thirty new stores, with eighteen twenty in the US, and ten twelve internationally.

Since the percentage of openings outside the US continues to rise, we may again see the actual openings be lower than the guidance, though management seemed optimistic that the actual would be closer to the budget than in FYfifteen.
With no clear catalyst visible at COST, we are maintaining our Equal Weight rating and dollar one hundred fifty price target.

Costco continues to operate some of the most productive stores across all of retail and we expect the company to continue to expand its store base.
Costco currently trades at a premium to many of its peers, as well as its historical valuation.
Upside to comps from already strong trends could result in further SG and A leverage and increase profitability.
Also the company's gross margin could benefit from continued strong fuel margins.
dollar one hundred fifty eight reflects twenty eightx our upside FYsixteen EPS of dollar five.seventy three.
Any disruption to membership renewals or further gross margin pressure from inflationary trends could hurt profitability.
dollar one hundred thirty reflects twenty fourx our downside FYsixteen EPS of dollar five.forty five.

THE MARKETING FOCUS AT COST IS MORE ABOUT CONSTANTLY IMPROVING THE VALUE PROPOSITION THAN GETTING TO KNOW INDIVIDUAL CUSTOMERS.

The company's membership model gives COST quite a bit of data about its members' shopping patterns, but it is only now starting to do some different things in its membership marketing, especially with digital.
The marketing group has gotten strong encouragement from senior management to try some new things.
This compares with other companies, including Kroger and CVS, which actively use individual customer data to provide personalized offerings.

One example of change that was mentioned on COST's fourQfifteen earnings call relates to the multi vendor mailer, which started out as a six or eight week summer item and has now been expanded to eleven mailings for three weeks each over the course of an entire year.
Management acknowledged that there a lot of low hanging fruit, however investors should not expect a big change any time soon.

It is unclear whether technology is a constraint, since the company is honest that it has been working with home grown, legacy systems for quite awhile, and the process of upgrading key systems is taking many years.

Also, one surprising comment that management made was to indicate that these potential initiatives can be implemented if the business slows, kind of like an extra tool kit, rather than as something to be done now.
Improving the value proposition to members ­ quality and price ­ gets the highest focus, but of course the company has other goals, like increasing average ticket.
For example, it will only increase the size of an item if the member gets a lower price per ounce or price per number of units.
It will also use savings from improved procurement or a lower cost for its credit card to improve the value of the merchandise it sells or the services it provides.
Car buying and travel services were both mentioned on the call as areas where COST can provide great value to members.
E COMMERCE IS A SMALL PORTION OF THE BUSINESS, BUT GROWING RAPIDLY.
Ecommerce sales grew over twenty percent in FYfifteen and reached dollar three.fiveB, or ~three percent of sales.
This strong growth rate was consistent throughout the year, and sales were also up ~twenty percent in fourQfifteen.
Customers use COST's e commerce platform for convenience or to gain access to a wider breadth of products.
It sells many large items online, but the expanded selection of product now includes frequently purchased items such as food, sundries, and office items as well.
COST is confident that its online business can be competitive because it believes it has the best overall pricing relative to other retailers.

Interestingly, given that the company's overall profit margin is low and its average ticket is quite high relative to other retailers, the online business is not as much of a drag to enterprise margin as it is to other brick and mortar retailers.
In fact, the ecommerce business operates at a margin that is at or just slightly below the company average.
When COST's e commerce business first started several years ago, all US orders were shipped out of one depot in Southern California.
Now COST uses several facilities which have resulted in a lower cost of shipping and also faster delivery to customers.
COST's e commerce growth has been boosted by its partnerships with Instacart, Google Express, and others.
We find it particularly interesting that Instacart users can place an order through it even if they don't have a membership at COST.
We assume there is some mark up over the COST shelf price that Instacart, and perhaps COST charges.
Even if there is a slight mark up, the price of bulk quantities may still be very attractive to many consumers given the retailer's low prices.
Instacart offers access to COST in fourteen states and Washington, D.C.
To purchase goods through Google Express, consumers need to be a club member.
With this interface, users can search for the same or similar items across retailers.
Barclays | Costco Wholesale Corp. low prices, we believe this type of search can favor COST relative to other retailers.
Searching for products this way may be introducing the retailer to new customers that are less familiar with the business.
Google Express is offered in many large cities throughout the US.

Lastly, our research suggests that COST is also a partner with other e commerce club store retailers such as Boxed, which is an e retailer that sells a limited selection of bulk items, similar to what can be found at a warehouse club.
Boxed does not require a club membership but it charges slightly higher prices than COST.
CAPEX WILL GO UP IN FYsixteen AS COST ACCELERATES UNIT GROWTH.
The company plans to add up to thirty net new warehouses in FYsixteen, up from twenty three in FYfifteen.

The new openings will be spread across all of the company's geographies, including eighteen twenty stores in the US and ten twelve internationally, located in Canada, Japan, Australia, the UK, Taiwan, Korea, Mexico, Spain, and France, which will be the company's newest country.
The company expects to open thirteen new warehouses in oneQsixteen, including two relocations, with nine of the openings in the US.
Next month, COST will also open its second unit in Spain, located in Madrid.
This new location will serve a larger market compared to the first warehouse in Spain, located in Seville, which opened in FYfourteen.
Also, for the next calendar year, COST is plans to open a third unit in Spain, located in Madrid as well.

In addition, management expects that towards the end of FYsixteen COST will finally open its first unit in France, a market where new store development is very difficult given regulatory restrictions.

Management believes COST can operate over one hundred warehouses in Canada long term, compared to eighty nine currently, and double the number of warehouses in Korea and Taiwan from twelve and eleven, respectively.
The company continues to find more opportunities to expand in the US than it previously thought and sees additional warehouse growth in Japan, which currently has twenty three warehouses.
Management forecast FYsixteen capital expenditures of dollar two.eight dollar three.
billion, up from dollar two.four billion in FYfifteen, driven by a higher number of warehouse openings, remodels, expansion of its crossdock operations, and IT.
The company expects capital expenditures to maintain a longterm run rate of dollar two.five dollar three.
Meanwhile, COST continues to remodel and expand warehouses, with a particular focus on increasing refrigerated and freezer capacity in its food segment.
The company has greatly expanded its walk in coolers for produce and other items that customers can use, and is expected to drive business in some stores.
In addition, management is constantly looking for locations to put additional gas stations, since fuel is a business that attracts customers and boosts COST's already strong price image.
percent, in line with our estimate, with SG and A as a percentage of twenty seven bp total revenue increasing twenty seven bp, to ten.

Guide to the Barclays Fundamental Equity Research Rating System: Our coverage analysts use a relative rating system in which they rate stocks as Overweight, Equal Weight or Underweight relative to other companies covered by the analyst or a team of analysts that are deemed to be in the same industry .
In addition to the stock rating, we provide industry views which rate the outlook for the industry coverage universe as Positive, Neutral or Negative .
A rating system using terms such as buy, hold and sell is not the equivalent of our rating system.
Investors should carefully read the entire research report including the definitions of all ratings and not infer its contents from ratings alone.
Stock Rating Overweight The stock is expected to outperform the unweighted expected total return of the industry coverage universe over a twelve month investment horizon.
Equal Weight The stock is expected to perform in line with the unweighted expected total return of the industry coverage universe over a twelvemonth investment horizon.
Underweight The stock is expected to underperform the unweighted expected total return of the industry coverage universe over a twelve month investment horizon.

Rating Suspended The rating and target price have been suspended temporarily due to market events that made coverage impracticable or to comply with applicable regulations and/or firm policies in certain circumstances including where the Investment Bank of Barclays Bank PLC is acting in an advisory capacity in a merger or strategic transaction involving the company.
Neutral industry coverage universe fundamentals/valuations are steady, neither improving nor deteriorating.
